name: Rep. Bonnie Watson Coleman
tweet_text:
My Stay Cool Act (HR 7949) would ensure that ALL communities can stay safe during deadly heat waves.

Among other things, my bill would invest in free public cooling spaces to make sure that everyone has a place to go when extreme heat strikes. (4/5)

name: Rep. Bonnie Watson Coleman
tweet_text:
Only three states — WA, VA, and my home state of NJ — have laws in place that prevent power from being shut off during deadly heat waves.

This leaves the rest of the US, including the hottest parts of the country, at risk.

We need a national plan to address this crisis. (3/5)

name: Rep. Bonnie Watson Coleman
tweet_text:
Underserved populations often lack steady access to A/C or ventilation. 16% of the US lives in energy poverty, meaning they spend more than 6% of their income paying their energy bills.

During heat waves, these Americans run the risk of having their power shut off. (2/5)

name: Rep. Bonnie Watson Coleman
tweet_text:
Extreme heat is the deadliest weather event we face. Black, Indigenous, & low-income communities have the highest rates of heat-related death.

Building heat-resilient communities isn't just a climate issue — it's a racial & economic justice issue. (1/5) 
https://t.co/M2MKOq3ux1

tweet_text: It’s no surprise that a member of the party that scores political points by spewing conspiratorial “great replacement” rhetoric and fomenting moral panics about so-called critical race theory in schools is perfectly comfortable ignoring the plight of Black American mothers. (5/8)

name: Rep. Bonnie Watson Coleman
tweet_text: GOP elected officials like Sen. Cassidy have no desire to dismantle these inequities — it’s easier for them to ignore them. Because dismantling health inequities means acknowledging systemic racism, and it’s against his best interests to do that. (4/8)

name: Rep. Bonnie Watson Coleman
tweet_text: Due to structural inequities built into our health care system. Black mothers are 3 times as likely to die due to complications from pregnancy than white mothers. In Louisiana, that number jumps to 4. (3/8)

name: Rep. Bonnie Watson Coleman
tweet_text:

name: Rep. Bonnie Watson Coleman
tweet_text: As Members of Congress, we must pass legislation that promotes diversity over discrimination and inclusivity over intolerance. For if we do so, we can create a fairer, more just world for young Black women and girls like my granddaughter to grow up in. (10/11)

name: Rep. Bonnie Watson Coleman
tweet_text:
With the CROWN Act, we can eliminate one such struggle. 

Although 188 of them blocked passage of my bill last month, I truly hope my Republican colleagues will take the opportunity today to stand against racial discrimination. (9/11)

name: Rep. Bonnie Watson Coleman
tweet_text: To write off hair discrimination as an unimportant issue is to suggest that Congress need not address the still-prevalent issue of systemic racism. This represents a blatant disregard for the struggles of Black people — especially Black women and girls — in our country. (8/11)

name: Rep. Bonnie Watson Coleman
tweet_text:
However, the Court encouraged Congress to bring clarity to this issue. With the CROWN Act, we’re doing just that.

Specifically, we are rightfully stating that discrimination against Black hair is discriminating against Black people, and that is unacceptable. (7/11)

name: Rep. Bonnie Watson Coleman
tweet_text: In EEOC v. Catastrophe Management Solutions, in which a Black prospective employee had her offer rescinded for refusing to alter her natural hair, the SCOTUS ruled that the policy was legal because it was supposedly race-neutral — despite discriminating against Black hair. (6/11)

name: Rep. Bonnie Watson Coleman
tweet_text:
Black people face discrimination in nearly all aspects of life — at the office, in the classroom and elsewhere — simply because of the way their hair naturally grows out of their head. 

In fact, hair discrimination has quite literally cost Black people their jobs. (5/11)

name: Rep. Bonnie Watson Coleman
tweet_text: Compared to, say, 20th-century Jim Crow laws, today’s racial discrimination is often more insidious. For instance, Black people face discrimination simply because the way their hair naturally grows has been deemed unacceptable. (4/11)

name: Rep. Bonnie Watson Coleman
tweet_text: Despite what my Republican colleagues might tell you, racism still runs rampant in America. As a Black woman who has lived through everything from the civil rights movement of the 1960s to today’s Black Lives Matter movement, I think I would know. (3/11)

name: Rep. Bonnie Watson Coleman
tweet_text:

The filibuster is ~185 years old. (It was first used in 1837.)

It has been changed over 161 times since 1969.

The word "filibuster" is not in the Constitution.

https://t.co/mWOgd3WF1W

name: Rep. Bonnie Watson Coleman
tweet_text:
RT @zellieimani: Today is Claudette Colvin’s 82nd birthday.  

On March 12, 1955, in Montgomery, Alabama, 15-year-old Claudette refused to…

name: Rep. Bonnie Watson Coleman
tweet_text:
The fate of American workers rests in the revitalization of the labor movement. 

Today, I celebrate their accomplishments with my brothers and sisters in the CWA and across the entire labor movement and wish all of you a safe and happy Labor Day.

name: Rep. Bonnie Watson Coleman
tweet_text: The brave women and men of the labor movement made their demands and built their power and with it built the American middle-class. It is no coincidence that as union membership has declined over the last 40 years, so too have wages remained flat and the middle-class has shrunk.

name: Rep. Bonnie Watson Coleman
tweet_text:
Institutions like OSHA, the National Labor Relations Board, and even Social Security are part of that legacy. 

Frederick Douglass said, “power concedes nothing without demand, it never has and never will.”

name: Rep. Bonnie Watson Coleman
tweet_text: By organizing and making collective demands, by demonstrating their collective power through strikes, slowdowns and boycotts, they were able to wrestle from their bosses some of the benefits that we take for granted: better wages, 8 hour day, safer working conditions and so on.

name: Rep. Bonnie Watson Coleman
tweet_text:
Happy #LaborDay weekend.

As you spend time with family and friends this weekend, keep in mind the sacrifices American workers have made. Men and women gave their literal blood, sweat, and tears to demand a better life for themselves, their families, and their fellow workers. https://t.co/8sbllKVmgp

name: Rep. Bonnie Watson Coleman

name: Rep. Bonnie Watson Coleman
tweet_text:
Next, the #DrugPolicyReform Act shifts drug policy from the Department of Justice to the Department of Health and Human Services. 
People struggling with drug addiction need doctors and counselors, not judges and jailers.

name: Rep. Bonnie Watson Coleman
tweet_text:
We waste a fortune prosecuting and locking up people for simple possession. 

Not to mention the harm it does to families and communities.

Our bill would has a health-based approach, not punitive approach.

name: Rep. Bonnie Watson Coleman
tweet_text:
The #DrugPolicyReform Act would end the War on Drugs and take a health-based, evidence-based approach. 

First, It decriminalizes drug use and possession.
This isn't free rein for dealers, its help for those struggling with addiction.

name: Rep. Bonnie Watson Coleman
tweet_text:
